Lina Seyfried

MainLife – The Event App for Freshmen

UX Case Study

Role

UX Researcher & Designer

Duration

10/22-03/23

Tools

Figma, Miro, Excel

01. Problem Statement

Moving to a new city for university can be an exciting yet overwhelming experience for first-year students. Social integration plays a crucial role in making students feel at home, but many struggle to find relevant events due to a lack of centralized information sources. This case study explores the design and development of MainLife, a mobile application aimed at facilitating first-year students' access to social events in Würzburg. The project was conducted as part of the Methods of User-Centered Design course in collaboration with the stadt.land.smart initiative.

Goal

First-year students face multiple barriers when trying to participate in social events:

  • Limited knowledge of the city and available events
  • Lack of a central platform for event information
  • Reliance on scattered sources such as WhatsApp groups, Instagram, and word of mouth
  • Difficulty in coordinating attendance with new acquaintances

The goal of MainLife was to create a user-centered solution that simplifies event discovery, provides relevant recommendations, and fosters social engagement.

02. Gathering User Data

User Research: Contextual Inquiries

To gain a deep understanding of the target group’s needs, we conducted contextual inquiries with six freshmen. We found that students primarily use two strategies for finding events:

  • Active Search: Actively searching through search engines or student council mailing lists.
  • Passive Discovery: Stumbling upon events via Instagram or WhatsApp groups.

Additional Insights

  • Lack of a central hub for event information
  • High importance of social groups in decision-making
  • Desire for an app with intuitive use and personalized recommendations

User Profiles

To create a solid foundation for the app design, we created detailed user profiles based on the interviews:

03. Consolidating User Data

Experience Models

Based on the contextual inquiries, we created the following experience models identify recurring patterns and to better understand user needs:

  • Identity Model: Characterized different user types (e.g., "The Planner," "The Partygoer," "The Spontaneous").
  • Day-in-the-Life Model: Illustrated typical daily user activities.
  • Relationship Model: Showed information flows between users and their social networks.

Affinity Diagram

After the interpretation sessions, an affinity diagram was created by grouping affinity notes into themes, needs, and problems. Notes were organized into clusters, refined iteratively, and labeled at different levels to form a hierarchical structure.

04. Ideation with User Data

Wall Walk

We began the ideation process with a Wall Walk to identify key user pain points generate potential solutions. This step served as a bridge between the research and the design phase, helping us explore technologies, features, and possible solutions.

Visioning

Through a Visioning Process, we explored multiple concepts before consolidating the most effective elements into a single vision.

The result was a smartphone application with the following key features:

  • Personalized Event Feed: Users receive tailored event recommendations based on their interests.
  • Integrated Social Features: Users can see which friends are attending an event and easily share events.
  • Smart Filtering & Calendar Integration: Users can filter events by category and save them to their personal calendar.
  • Minimalist & Intuitive UI: The design prioritizes usability and clarity to reduce cognitive load.

04. Design & Prototyping

We created a paper prototype to quickly test and refine these ideas before moving to digital prototyping.

05. Validating the Product

We then conducted usability testing in two iterations with six participants each, gathering feedback and making improvements after each round. Key refinements included:

  • Simplified Registration Process: Users found the initial onboarding too complex, so we streamlined it.
  • Improved Event Filtering: Users requested more specific filtering options to quickly find relevant events.
  • Enhanced Navigation & UI Clarity: Adjustments were made to the app layout to improve ease of use.

06. Final Solution

The MainLife app offers a personalized event feed, social features for group events, and an interactive map for easy navigation. A minimalist interface ensures intuitive use.

07. Lessons Learned

  • User-Centered Design is Essential:Contextual Inquiries provided valuable insights that shaped our design decisions.
  • Iterative Prototyping Improves Usability: Continuous testing helped refine features and eliminate pain points.
  • Diverse User Recruitment Matters: The initial sample consisted mainly of female students from similar academic backgrounds, which may have biased results.
